titleInfo.title: Louisiana Cooperative Extension Oral History Project
titleInfo.subTitle: William Richardson oral history interview, 2014

name.description: William Richardson was born in southeast Missouri in 1944 to William Richardson, Sr. and Pauline Gunnin. He was raised on a soybean-cotton farm near Kennett, Missouri. He attended Dearing public schools until he graduated from high school. After high school, he attended Arkansas State University, where he earned a B.S. degree in 1966, and a master's degree in 1968. He received his doctorate degree in agricultural education from the University of Missouri in 1972. From 1972 until 1984, he taught at Purdue University, where he was recognized twice as an Outstanding Teacher, and once as an Outstanding Academic Advisor by the University's Department of Education. He joined the faculty of Louisiana State University as a professor in 1984. He has served in various national and international leadership capacities as well as in numerous administrative capacities and on many boards and committees. He's published numerous articles and textbooks, and has served as the chairperson for various master's theses and doctoral dissertations. He currently serves as Director of Louisiana Cooperative Extension Service and LSU Vice-President for Agriculture and Dean for the College of Agriculture.

mods.abstract: Richardson begins the interview by speaking about his grandparents. He also discusses life in rural Missouri and what it was like to live on a farm in the Kennett area. This includes social outlets such as cruising, going to the movies, basic farm chores, crops, and a typical workday on the farm. He also details his time at Arkansas State University. He discusses mandatory ROTC service, the basketball team, and what college campuses were like during the sixties and the Vietnam War era. Richardson notes the differences between college athletes today and when he was in school, the political awareness of students today versus his time in school, and what it was like to play with the first black basketball player at Arkansas State University. He notes how those experiences helped him to be more diverse as an administrator later in his career. Richardson also discusses how people depended on extension agents for information. County agents helped deliver information to the people in a much different manner than today. Today's agents have more technology and other avenues to disseminate information, though their motivations remain the same.
